intro: Pastinaca sekakul, commonly known as the wild parsnip, is a biennial plant belonging to the Apiaceae family. It is characterized by its smooth, green stems and large, fern-like leaves that are divided into numerous segments. The plant produces yellow flowers in umbrella-like clusters, typical of the carrot family. Its root is cylindrical and often has a mild, sweet scent, though it is not typically consumed by humans. It is native to Europe and parts of Asia but has been introduced to other regions, including North America.
